Posts.Content: Hi penny I understand exactly how you feel. Nothing can prepare you for a cancer dx. I had a core biopsy which came back as positive for cancer. They can normally be pretty sure from the ultrasound whether there is a likelihood that your lump is malignant and my consultant basically told me straight out that he believed it was cancer. He would not have done so if he had any doubt. If it is cancer please take some comfort from one who knows that it is not a death sentence. I was first dx 14 years ago aged 31 and I am still here to tell the tale. I have been unfortunate as I have just had another primary dx this year, and although disappointing having been through this once already I am taking heart from the fact that I was cured of the last cancer as it has never recurred and this is an entirely new incidence. I hope all goes well for you - please let me know how you get on Love Kaz x
Posts.Title: worried

Posts.Content: Hi - I am new to this site having been diagnosed for a second time with bc. I first had bc 14 years ago and was treated with lumpectomy, wide excision, radiotherapy and Tamoxifen. I have just had surgery to the other breast for another primary tumour and had another lumpectomy, wide excision and sentinel node biopsy which turned out to be clear. I am awating further results on Monday to find out more about recommended treatment but my consultant advised that initial biopsy indicated grade 3 cancer and so chemotherapy would be advised. This terrifies me. I found radiotherapy no problem last time and wonder if it is really necessary to have chemo if there is no evidence of any spread this time also. It does also worry me the potential risks in having these treatments as my consultant always worried about sending me for too many mammograms because of the potential risk of causing cancer from too much radiation. I suppose it is the lesser of two evil scenario. I would be really interested in hearing from others who have been through chemo and those who rejected it love Karen x

Posts.Content: Hi Karen It is strange how treatment can differ between health authorities isn't it. I have also been reading that triple negative cancers can benefit greatly from a regime combined with a taxane so I am going to ask my onc about it when I see him on Thursday. It is so difficult to know what you should be having for the best isn't it and I suppose we have to just have faith in the experts and go along with what they recommend. Posts.Content: Hi KTB Your post has been very reassuring to me - I too feel that a few months feeling poorly is worth it if it means I get to live a longer healthier life. I am sure once I get started with the chemo I will not feel so frightened by it as I am sure my imagination of what it will be like is far worse than the real thing will be. Good luck with your final 3 FEC. I found the radiotherapy first time around not bad at all and I had 4 weeks then as opposed to the 3 weeks I will be having this time around. Admittedly, last time I had radiotherapy it was not straight after having endured chemo so maybe the tiredness will be worse having it after chemo when you are still probably recovering your strength - but I have to say having the radiotherapy does not worry me and I am sure you will be fine with it too. Kaz x

Posts.Content: Hi Linfel Your case sounds very similar to my own. I too was diagnosed 14 years ago and had just radiotherapy as lumpectomy was successful and nodes were clear. I wasn't offered chemo then though so did not have to make a decision. Now I have another primary in other breast - 1.2cm , grade 3, clear SNB and stage 1. Because it is a grade 3 and I am pre menopausal at age 46 I have been recommended to have chemo as a precaution. Am scared to have the chemo which is due to start on 19th March ( 6 x FEC ) but scared not to have it too. Have you any results yet on your new bc and what recommendations are they making this time ? Kaz x
